title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement jung@iiasa. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

what: The BNRTools package - Helper functions for IIASA researchers
title: The BNRTools package - Helper functions for IIASA researchers
text: repository contains common set functions scripts used BNR Researchers. ’s purpose avoid replication efforts across different groups maintain common scripts structured way. Use cases might example include reprojection certain grids, conversion model output formats different format types generic commonly used helper functions.

title: The BNRTools package - Helper functions for IIASA researchers
text: Every BNR researcher can suggest add new functions package. maximize understanding usability, please stick following house rules: main branch contains stable functions. dev branch hot updates. avoid merging conflicts preferably create new branch named pull request dev. Functions stored R folder one script per file. New scripts functions named camelCase prefix suggesting content, e.g. spatial file sp_aggregateNUTS. script least minimal documentation title, description, parameters, example output function. possible add unit tests function catch wrong inputs early . See website general help examples developing content R-packages.

title: The BNRTools package - Helper functions for IIASA researchers
text: BNRTools package can installed either remotes R-package directly r-universe.
code: # Install from source remotes::install_github("iiasa/BNRTools") # Or for the current development branch remotes::install_github("iiasa/BNRTools", "dev")  # Installation  install.packages('BNRTools', repos = "https://iiasa.r-universe.dev")

title: The BNRTools package - Helper functions for IIASA researchers
text: Please note BNRTools project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: The BNRTools package - Helper functions for IIASA researchers
text: contributions project gratefully acknowledged using allcontributors package following -contributors specification. Contributions kind welcome!

what: Table with default paths to commonly used spatial input files — bnr_datapaths
title: Table with default paths to commonly used spatial input files — bnr_datapaths
text: dataset contains path names commonly-used spatial data files. Given files usually quite large, describe find internally upload data . Medium-long-term improved relying github LFS systems gitlab instance.

title: Table with default paths to commonly used spatial input files — bnr_datapaths
Table with default paths to commonly used spatial input files — bnr_datapaths
text: data.frame containing paths key spatial data sources.

title: Table with default paths to commonly used spatial input files — bnr_datapaths
text: Manually updated curated BNR researchers

title: Table with default paths to commonly used spatial input files — bnr_datapaths
text: file following columns: * 'drive': path drive data stored (Default: 'P:/bnr/'). Can system dependent (Windows/Linux). * 'access': non-structured field containing list people access (example 'IBF' 'bnr'). * 'group': field entry describing file belongs (.e. "EPIC"). * 'filename': actual filename

title: Table with default paths to commonly used spatial input files — bnr_datapaths
text: update overwrite, load file update, apply usethis::use_data(bnr_datapaths, overwrite = TRUE) .

what: Function to format a prepared GLOBIOM netCDF file for use in ibis.iSDM — conv_downscalr2ibis
title: Function to format a prepared GLOBIOM netCDF file for use in ibis.iSDM — conv_downscalr2ibis
text: function expects downscaled GLOBIOM output created BIOCLIMA project. converts input stars object fed ibis.iSDM R-package.

title: Function to format a prepared GLOBIOM netCDF file for use in ibis.iSDM — conv_downscalr2ibis
code: conv_downscalr2ibis(   fname,   ignore = NULL,   period = "all",   template = NULL,   shares_to_area = FALSE,   use_gdalutils = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Function to format a prepared GLOBIOM netCDF file for use in ibis.iSDM — conv_downscalr2ibis
text: fname filename character pointing GLOBIOM output netCDF format. ignore vector variables ignored (Default: NULL). period character limiting period returned formatted data. Options include "reference" first entry, "projection" entries first, "" entries (Default: "reference"). template optional SpatRaster object towards projects transformed. shares_to_area logical whether shares corrected areas (identified). use_gdalutils (Deprecated) logical use gdalutils hack-around. verbose logical whether chatty.

title: Function to format a prepared GLOBIOM netCDF file for use in ibis.iSDM — conv_downscalr2ibis
text: SpatRaster stack formatted GLOBIOM predictors.

title: Function to format a prepared GLOBIOM netCDF file for use in ibis.iSDM — conv_downscalr2ibis
text: Martin Jung

title: Function to format a prepared GLOBIOM netCDF file for use in ibis.iSDM — conv_downscalr2ibis
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ ## Does not work unless downscalr file is provided. # Expects a filename pointing to a netCDF file. covariates <- conv_downscalr2ibis(fname) } # }

what: Shows size of objects in the R environment — misc_objectSize
title: Shows size of objects in the R environment — misc_objectSize
text: Shows size objects currently R environment. Helps locate large objects cluttering R environment /causing memory problems execution large workflows.

title: Shows size of objects in the R environment — misc_objectSize
Shows size of objects in the R environment — misc_objectSize
text: n Number objects show, Default: 10

title: Shows size of objects in the R environment — misc_objectSize
text: data frame row names indicating object name, field 'Type' indicating object type, 'Size' indicating object size, columns 'Length/Rows' 'Columns' indicating object dimensions applicable.

title: Shows size of objects in the R environment — misc_objectSize
text: Bias Benito

title: Shows size of objects in the R environment — misc_objectSize
code: if(interactive()){   #creating dummy objects  x <- matrix(runif(100), 10, 10)  y <- matrix(runif(10000), 100, 100)   #reading their in-memory size  misc_objectSize()  }

title: Sanitize variable names — misc_sanitizeNames
text: Prepared covariates often special characters variable names can can used formulas cause errors certain procedures. function converts special characters (points, underscores similar) variable names species format.

title: Sanitize variable names — misc_sanitizeNames
Sanitize variable names — misc_sanitizeNames
text: names vector character vectors sanitized.

title: Sanitize variable names — misc_sanitizeNames
text: vector sanitized character.

title: Sanitize variable names — misc_sanitizeNames
code: # Correct variable names vars <- c("Climate-temperature2015", "Elevation__sealevel", "Landuse.forest..meanshare") misc_sanitizeNames(vars) #> ℹ Note: Method deprecated. Just janitor::make_clean_names() directly! #> [1] "climate_temperature2015"  "elevation_sealevel"       #> [3] "landuse_forest_meanshare"

what: RExport a gridded raster to a NetCDF format — spl_exportNetCDF
title: RExport a gridded raster to a NetCDF format — spl_exportNetCDF
text: function serves general wrapper function export provided spatial gridded layer multi-dimensional NetCDF file. furthermore requires specification list containing metadata information.

title: RExport a gridded raster to a NetCDF format — spl_exportNetCDF
code: spl_exportNetCDF(   obj,   filename,   global_meta = system.file("iiasa_meta.yaml", package = "BNRTools"),   separate_meta = FALSE,   ... )

title: RExport a gridded raster to a NetCDF format — spl_exportNetCDF
text: obj SpatRaster object exported. filename character output filename. global_meta global metadata descriptor default using IIASA standard metadata (Default: "iiasa_meta data"). separate_meta logical flag whether metadata written separately "yaml" format (Default: FALSE). ... metadata overwritten added "global_meta".

title: RExport a gridded raster to a NetCDF format — spl_exportNetCDF
text: default metadata contained "inst/iiasa_meta". See examples.

title: RExport a gridded raster to a NetCDF format — spl_exportNetCDF
text: support 'stars' added.

title: RExport a gridded raster to a NetCDF format — spl_exportNetCDF
text: Martin Jung

title: RExport a gridded raster to a NetCDF format — spl_exportNetCDF
code: # Load default metadata (loaded by default by function too) meta <- yaml::read_yaml(system.file("iiasa_meta.yaml", package = "BNRTools"))  # Dummy raster obj <- terra::rast(ncol = 100, nrow = 100,                    xmin = 0, xmax = 100,                    ymin = 0, ymax = 100,                    resolution = 5, crs = terra::crs("WGS84"),                    val = runif(400)                    )  # Export spl_exportNetCDF(obj, filename = "test.nc",                      global_meta = meta, title = "Super cool analysis") #> ✔ Succesfully written output format!

what: Replace NA values in gridded layers with a fixed value. — spl_replaceGriddedNA
title: Replace NA values in gridded layers with a fixed value. — spl_replaceGriddedNA
text: function replaces NA values spatial gridded layer fixed value example 0. Accepted input layers SpatRaster "terra" R-package stars "stars" R-package.

title: Replace NA values in gridded layers with a fixed value. — spl_replaceGriddedNA
Replace NA values in gridded layers with a fixed value. — spl_replaceGriddedNA
text: obj SpatRaster, SpatRasterDataset stars object. value fixed numeric value NA values replaced (Default: 0). mask optional SpatRaster object used instead value. verbose chatty processed (Default: FALSE).

title: Replace NA values in gridded layers with a fixed value. — spl_replaceGriddedNA
text: object type input -data values replaced 'value'.

title: Replace NA values in gridded layers with a fixed value. — spl_replaceGriddedNA
text: Required inputs single "obj" gridded data object numeric value. addition optional mask layer can provided use mask. case -data values replaced value mask.

title: Replace NA values in gridded layers with a fixed value. — spl_replaceGriddedNA
text: Martin Jung

title: Replace NA values in gridded layers with a fixed value. — spl_replaceGriddedNA
code: # Example s <- terra::rast(system.file("ex/logo.tif", package="terra")) s[sample(1:terra::ncell(s), 100)] <- NA sfill <- spl_replaceGriddedNA(s, value = 100) terra::plot(sfill)

title: Resample raster — spl_resampleRas
text: Resample two raster spatial resolution using aggregation disaggregation.

title: Resample raster — spl_resampleRas
Resample raster — spl_resampleRas
text: x SpatRaster resampled. y SpatRaster x resampled discrete logical specifiy input raster continitous discrete values

title: Resample raster — spl_resampleRas
text: SpatRaster

title: Resample raster — spl_resampleRas
code: set.seed(42) ras_a <- terra::rast(ncol = 100, nrow = 100, xmin = 0, xmax = 100, ymin = 0, ymax = 100, resolution = 20, crs = NA)  ras_b <- terra::rast(ncol = 100, nrow = 100, xmin = 0, xmax = 100, ymin = 0, ymax = 100, resolution = 5, crs = NA)   terra::values(ras_a) <- runif(n = terra::ncell(ras_a))  terra::values(ras_b) <- runif(n = terra::ncell(ras_b))   spl_resampleRas(x = ras_a, y = ras_b) #> class       : SpatRaster  #> dimensions  : 20, 20, 1  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) #> resolution  : 5, 5  (x, y) #> extent      : 0, 100, 0, 100  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #> coord. ref. :   #> source(s)   : memory #> name        :      lyr.1  #> min value   : 0.08243756  #> max value   : 0.98361379
